11/ Don't let FinTech fraud derail your growth. Come talk to us @sardineai

If you liked this thread, follow me for more "phishy stories".

10/ Stories like these are why at @sardineai we designed our fraud prevention platform from the ground up.

Our behavior-based platform detects fraudulent sign-ups: whether made by bots, data centers, emulators, virtual machines, and device farms â€” before they cause damage.
9/ Another way to achieve this level of unity could involve having both leaders of the Fraud and Growth teams report to the head of a business unit.

8/ Place your organizational structures in alignment:

When I was at @coinbase, my Data Science team was  renamed to â€œRisk and Growth,â€ and we became responsible for both maximizing the metrics around the companyâ€™s referral programs as well as minimizing the fraud rates.

7/ The answer is to align incentives by having company-wide metrics that balance both growth and fraud rates. 

Hereâ€™s one example: Reduce and maintain fraud rates at less than 20 basis points (BPS) while increasing the 90-day LTV from the current $80 to $100.

6/ Align your internal stakeholders by using proper metrics:

if your fraud team only cares about reducing fraud rate, thatâ€™s just half the battle. If your growth team only cares about increasing sign-ups (w/o looking at quality of  sign-ups), thatâ€™s also half the battle.

5/ Incentivize with premium features instead of cold cash:

Instead of offering both the referee and referral $5 for a sign-up, give them both some credits for using your product instead. eg $5 of free instant FX conversions, 5 free ATM withdrawals, or 5 fee-free crypto buys.

4/ Add fraud rates to your Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC) to Lifetime Value (LTV) formula

No point in launching a growth program if you have a leaky funnel or if most of your CAC dollars are going straight into fraudstersâ€™ pockets.

3/ With @PayPal's challenges in mind, I thought Iâ€™d share a few thoughts about how FinTech and crypto founders can prevent their customer acquisition programs from getting derailed. 

Here are 4 ways for FinTech leaders to keep fraud out of the equation:

2/ The main lesson based on my years of experience fighting fraud at @coinbase, @RevolutApp  and now @sardineai, is the following: 

"If you are leading a FinTech or a crypto company, you canâ€™t let fraud blindside you. It will be a costly oversight"

1/ During an earnings call this week, @PayPal  admitted that 4.5 million of its account sign-ups were fraudulent. If you ever needed proof that FinTech fraud is out of control, this was it. Following the call, PayPalâ€™s stock dropped 25 percent.
